Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research:Network Innovation Through Choice

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Computer networks, in particular the Internet, represent critical infrastructure for business, government, military, and personal communication. Several recent trends in technology and network use have pushed the capabilities required of the Internet beyond what can be provided by the currently deployed infrastructure. This project develops a new architectural design for the Internet of the near future that represents a transformative shift to enable sustained innovation in the core of the network, using economic principles. The core idea of this new network architecture is to support choice as the central aspect of the architecture. A network built on these principles will be able to adapt to emerging solutions for current and future challenges. The network architecture designed and prototyped in this work aims to (1) encourage alternatives to allow users to choose from a range of services, (2) let users vote with their wallet to reward superior and innovative services, (3) provide the mechanisms to stay informed on available alternatives and their performances. Solutions are approached from different directions, reflecting the team?' multidisciplinary expertise in computer networking, network systems, management science, and network economics.

The broader impact of this project contributes to enhancing the functionality and usability of the next-generation Internet, which is expected to become an important piece of infrastructure. The project also integrates research and education of graduate and undergraduate students at the participating organizations, where current efforts to integrate underrepresented minorities are continued. Results from this work are disseminated in the form of an open-source prototype and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Internet is the undisputed cyber-backbone of the modern world, enabling education, commerce, governance, business, infrastructure – just about every aspect of life.  Yet for a long time, improvement in the Internet has only meant more and more bandwidth.  Researchers and practitioners have imagined futuristic functionality that could operate in an enhanced Internet, and enable advanced networked systems of ubiquitous, mobile, integrated computing and communications.  But they have been hard to realize.  The Internet of today is much faster than that of yesteryear, or ten years ago, but otherwise works hardly any better – while during the same time computing devices, applications, machine-to-machine applications, have exploded in a variety hard to encompass. 

What changes might be made to the current architecture that would enable accelerating innovation, and contribution by a wide range of innovators?  One answer is provided by considering how such innovators are motivated.  In an “app store” model, different innovators can bring their offerings directly to potential users of their innovation.  These users are in the position of rewarding the offerings they find useful by buying them; the users are also customers.  Customers directly interacting with providers of innovative advances by “voting with their wallet”, over time, encourages the emergence of an ecosystem in which effective innovators are consistently rewarded, and therefore, motivated.

The reason the networking ecosystem does not work similarly to reward innovation is that the innovator is at least thrice removed from the customers that their innovations benefit.  Innovative mechanisms, software or hardware, must be placed in network devices, which are manufactured in device vendors.  Device vendors sell such devices to network operators such as Internet Service Providers, who in turn provide the services that customers use.  There is no way for a customer to make the decision to use some innovative feature but not others, or to earmark their network usage costs to reward features they benefit from.  Indeed, there is no way for a customer to discern what features make up the network service they receive.

The ChoiceNet project aimed at defining the architectural extensions to the Internet that would allow an ecosystem in which (i) customers know the various service components that can be combined to provide the overall service they need, (ii) customers are able to make choices as to which specific service alternatives they will use for a given purpose, and pay the corresponding providers directly, and (iii) customers can discern what performance each service components provided.  Further, the project aimed at investigating, in simulated circumstances, whether such mechanisms can indeed interact to improve the overall efficiency of networks.

During the project, we completed the description of such an architectural system, implemented and demonstrated it in prototype, and proved through simulations its potential beneficial effects on network operation if adopted in the real world.  We have published and presented our technical results at appropriate academic conferences.  Below we provide a brief overview of the main components of the ChoiceNet architecture. 

The architectural interactions and entities that the ChoiceNet architecture proposes together make up what we call the Economy Plane.  Using economy plane interactions, providers can advertise service alternatives in a marketplace.  No service that is of value can be assumed to be free, so the marketplace is itself provided by a marketplace provider.  Customers use the economy plane to find out service alternatives from the marketplace.  They make choices between equivalent alternative service components, and use the economy plane to purchase the chosen service alternatives from the respective providers, who provision the respective service components, and compose them into the end-to-end service the customer needs.  Monitoring services purchased by the customer provide measurements to the customer that enables the customer to know which service components performed as expected, and which did not.  On subsequent interactions, customers tend to prefer the service alternatives that performed well, and abandon ones that did not.

With the emergence of paradigms like Software Defined Networking, the ChoiceNet architecture can be readily implemented in realistic systems, as we have done in our prototypes.  In other fields of computing, we have seen that the lowering of barriers to innovation (and to the deployment and penetration of innovative services) leads to an explosive broadening of the community of innovators, and broad democratization of the field. We fully expect that the ChoiceNet project will contribute to such a democratization, since it specifically aims at lowering such barriers for innovative networking services.
